Dear Bay:
By the time you receive this, you will have returned from Columhus.
The thanksgiving period recenC-ly ended apparently slowed the mails, as I

When Art Weld first showed me the Hovemher 22 information cojjy

I was sorry to miss the meeting because of the fun of greeting
old friends and meeting new ones, and the profit to be obtained from
the work. But I know you^ll havehlad a successful meeting, and I can
hope that I might sometime read a report of the activities.
My real regret was the (shall I say—slipshod) way in which
HASB headquarters handled the matter. Your letter was the first in¬
dication that I was no longer a member of the research committee I I
knew that you had been newly appointed as chairman last spring when
you chaired a panel at Columbus, but (and please forgive me for harboring
such thoughts) I Just assumed that lack of correspondence meant lack
of activity on the part of the committeeJ I never dreamed I had been
removed. Having served since my initial ai^pointment in January, 1953*
I had the mistaken impression that I would remain a member until my
interest and talents, or NABB*s policies, detennined otherwise.
Obviously the latter happened; but the communication sure fell
down somewhere. Indeed, when I sent in the i^ecent telecourse sirrvey to
K.S., he asked if I had sent copies to the Research Committee, and I
replied tha.t I had sent them to you, Adkins, Harwood, Coleman,, and
Remmers. I see now that I missed Becker, Flick, Merrill, and Tyler,
but I*m sure they^ll forgive mej
Do I recall talk at St. Louis that a “summit” meeting for NABB

Sincerely,
